Substitute: v=y/x
d/dx (vx)=1/2v+3v/2
Applying product rule,
x dv/dx+v=(1+3v^2)/2v
dv/dx=(1+v^2)/2vx
Separating the variables and integrating,
∫▒2vdv/(1+v^2 )=∫▒dx/x
*and then we see Einstein solving this….
ln⁡(Cx)=ln⁡(1+v^2 )
v=y/x

text:
Motion is described as time. Perhaps we can describe time. In that life is the very thing we call
time. There is no time, but life and space. A tree grows, not by time but in
space. It is not controlled by time. And neither is man controlled by time,
time is an illusion. There's no such thing as separate times. Past, present,
& future ALL exist at the same time. How you perceive time's just an
illusion. Time doesn't exist. It's a human invention, to put a label on the
transition of states of a piece of matter. The future doesn't exist and the
past doesn't exist, the only thing that exist is the state of the matter in the
present. Time isn’t absolute.﻿

author: Raju Asalkar

text: For an historical film, it included an error which any decent fact-checker would have caught: Mozart's metronome could not have existed because it was not invented until 1812, Beethoven's time, years after Mozart's death in 1791. This sadly casts a shadow of doubt over other assertions of facts which I may not know as I watch the film. I'll always be asking if "X" is so, when I know this easily checkable assertion was incorrect. Had the script said "Beethoven's metronome" it would have been quite accurate, since it is well documented that he used the metronome to place tempo markings in his pre-metronome scores.﻿

author: Danek Rodů

text:
This is true, but the answer in the video is actually correct.  Einstein uses change of variables  eg. v = y/x => dy/dx = v + xdv/dx. Substituting this back in and rearranging leads to
(2vdv)/(1+v^2)=dx/x
Which is also why the wild variable v suddenly appears.

Integrating both sides of this eq. takes us to the point where he starts his answer in the video:
log(1+v^2) = log(Cx)﻿

author: Moist

Nice thing is they left the cosmological constant out of the field equations, Einstein once said it was his "biggest blunder" and didn't really believe it belongs there.
